text: Meeting of the transportation utilities committee will come to order.
The time is 9:30 A.M.
I'm Alex Pedersen, chair of the committee.
Will the clerk please call the roll.
Council President Gonzalez.
Present.
Councilmember Herbold.
Here.
Councilmember Morales.
Here.
Councilmember Strauss.
Present.
Chair Pedersen.
Present.
Five present.
Thank you.
Quick update on our committee agenda.
One of the transit Advisesy board appointees is no longer available to serve so if there's no objection we will remove agenda item 4 which was appointment 2075.
So we'll remove that agenda item.
Removing agenda item 4. hearing no objection, item 4 is removed.
And if there's no objection we'll adopt the amended agenda.
Hearing no objection the agenda is adopted.
Good morning.
Welcome to the second to last meeting of the transportation and utilities committee of 2021.
This is also the last meeting from which items voted out of this committee will be able to go to full council before the end of the year.
That's because the last full council meeting of this year will be on December 13, but our next committee meeting is not until December 15.
Today's agenda includes four mayoral appointments to transportation boards.
A presentation on Council member Mosqueda's proposal to waive fees for publicly funded affordable housing projects.
Councilmember Mosqueda might join us for that.
So at this time we will open the remote general public comment period.
I ask that everyone please be patient as we operate this Online system.
We are continuously looking for ways to fine tune this process.
It remains a strong intent of the city Council to have public comment regularly included on meeting Agendas.

However the city council reserves the right to modify these if it we deem the system is being abused or is unsuitable for allowing our meetings to be conducted efficiently and in a manner in which we're able to conduct our necessary business.
I will moderate the public comment period in the following manner.
Public comment period for this meeting will be up to 20 minutes.
Each Speaker will be given two minutes to speak.
Call on the speakers two at a time in the order in which they're registered.
If you've not yet registered to speak but would like to, you can sign up before the end of this public comment period by going to the Council's Website Seattle.Gov/Council.
The public comment link is also listed on today's committee agenda.

Once I call a Speaker's name, staff will Unmute the appropriate microphone an automatic prompt will be the Speaker's Cue that it is their turn to speak and the Speaker must press Star 6 to begin speaking.
Press Star 6. please begin speaking by stating your name and the item you are addressing.
As a reminder, public comment should relate to an item on today's agenda.
Speakers will hear a Chime when 10 seconds are left of the a Lotted time.
Once you hear the Chime we ask that you begin to wrap up your public comment.
If speakers do not end their comments at the end of the a Lotted time the Speaker's microphone will be muted to allow us to call on the next Speaker.

Once you've completed your public comment we ask that you please Disconnect from the line and if you plan to continue following this meeting you can do so via Seattle channel or the listening options listed on the agenda.
If you are calling about Council bill 120320 or resolution 32030, please wait until later in the agenda for the public hearings on those two items.
They each have their own public hearing.
The regular public comment period for this committee meeting is now open.
And we will begin with the first Speaker on the list.
Actually we have just one Speaker so far.
That is Max Baker.
Please press Star 6 and go ahead.
Hi.
Apologies if I don't have an item related to today's agenda but I wanted to speak generally to the proposed transportation plan and a bit about the vision zero plan of the past.
Ten years ago I came upon a dead cyclist in the road who had been hit by a truck just minutes before and that image sticks with me today.
Especially now that I bike these streets with my toddler every day.
When Delridge showed up a as protected bike Lane priority I was excited to think this area has become safe.
I voted strongly because of this.
Remove bike lanes as advocacy groups and residents pushed back.
Then the pandemic came along and the bridge closed.
Bike sales skyrocketed.
With a 1500% increase in bike trips.
Nothing actually changed to the plans themselves.
Delridge is done and what we have is Street parking where nearly every business and home has Offstreet parking and dedicated turn lanes.
We were provided with a bike Lane that only goes one way without a return option it's essentially useless.
I still see bikers Honked at by cars.
Why are they still Biking here?
This was the one flat route and everything for locals is here on the street.
The schools accident the day cares, the libraries, the community center.
We'll just go bike on the Greenway.
You mean the Greenway where last summer I witnessed a car turn on to without slowing?
Had someone been in that street they surely would have been killed.
I do not exaggerate when I say this every friend we have or made has moved.
One told me the moments they were moving the Northbound bike Lane in Ront of her house was the moment she decided to move.
City dedicated to reducing its dependence on cars.
Continues to push Nonvehicle transportation further down its priorities.
Thank you very much for those comments and please send the rest of your comments to the Council.
You can send it to Council @ Seattle.Gov or you can send it to me as the chair.
Thank you.
This concludes the list of speakers from the general public.
Let me just double check that.
Yes.
Yes.
That concludes the list of speakers from the general public.
Now we'll move on to the first legislative item on the agenda.
Will the clerk please read the title of the first two agenda items into the record.
Agenda items 1 and 2, appointments 2072 and 2073.
Appointments of Jose Ulises Nino Rivera and Diane Teh-Mei Walsh as members Seattle bicycle advise raise board for terms to August 31, 2023.
For briefing, discussion and possible vote.
Thank you.
Yes, these are two mayoral appointments.
The Seattle bike board.
Appreciate their willingness to serve.
We'll turn it over to Simon Blenski from Sdot to tell us about the board and these two new members and their appointment packets are on the agenda.
If they're here with us we'll get to hear from them.
Hi, Simon.
Good morning.
Good morning.
Yeah, Jose and Diane are both here.
My name is Simon Blenski.
I'm transportation planner with Sdot and I'm also the staff liaison for the bicycle advisory board.
The Mayor, city Council and city departments on projects, policies and programs that improve or affect conditions in Seattle.
The board has 12 members.
I'm here to recommend the appointment of two new members for two year terms through August of 2023.
I will hand it over next to Jose to say a few words and introduce himself then followed by Diane.
Thank you.
Welcome.
Hi, can you hear me?
Yes.
Great.
My name is Jose Ulises Nino Rivera.
I'm being appointed for my first full term to the Seattle bicycle advisory board.
This term I hope to focus on ensuring by infrastructure is the sign and build to encourage people to encourage people from all ages and abilities to shift transportation to Biking.
One of the best avenues we have in reducing carbon emissions in the personal transportation sector.
Something we need to accomplish if we want to combat the existential threat of climate change.
Thanks for giving me the opportunity to serve the city.
Thank you for serving us.
Welcome.
Diane, welcome.
Sorry.
Hi, my name is Diane Walsh.
A little bit of background about myself.

I've been in Seattle for the past ten years where I moved up here for a masters of landscape architecture at Uw and then moved on to work at Sdot in the public space management program where I worked on programs to activate the right of way.
I view Bicycling and good bicycle infrastructure as an integral part of our functioning transportation system and a way to make the city more vibrant and people centered.

I personally bike as my primary form of transportation when I can because of the personal and social and environmental benefits, but I realize that not everybody has access to Biking in this way so would like to reduce some of those barriers to entry.
I have two kids who are now of Biking age where they can ride in the road and it's kind of terrifying.
So I think that I would like to help advocate for and imagine a city where a 4 or 5-Year-Old could safely and comfortably bike through any part of the city.
So I'm very excited about the prospect of being on the board.
Thanks.
Thank you.
Council members, any questions for these two mayoral appointees to the Seattle bike advisory board?
I know you've all read the packets.
Sometimes we don't have any questions.
And that's fine.
I certainly appreciate your willingness to serve and Jose, continuing to serve.

Look forward to hearing from the bike board directly, as well as they have a liaison to the move Seattle levy oversight committee which is helpful to integrate when talking about all modes of transportation to have Cycling advocates at the table there as well.
All right.
Well, Council members, I would like to move that the committee recommend approval of appointments 2072 and 2073 items 1 and 2 on our agenda.
Is there a second?
Second.
It's been moved and Seconded.
Recommended approval of these appointments.
Any final comments?
Will the clerk please call the roll.
Gonzalez.
Aye.
Herbold.
Yes.
Morales.
Yes.
Strauss.
Yes.
Chair Pedersen.
Yes.
Five in favor, none opposed.
Thank you.
The motion carries.
The committee recommendation that the appointments be confirmed will be sent to the December 6th city council meeting.
Congratulations to our appointees for moving to the next step.
Thank you for joining us today as well.
Will the clerk please read the title of the next agenda item into the record?
Agenda item 3. appointment 2074.
Appointment of Amin Amos for a term to August 2, 2023 for briefing, discussion and possible vote.
Great.

We have NICO from Sdot here with us and as I mentioned before, the other appointment is no longer available to serve but really appreciate the appointee who is here this morning with us and we'll hear from NICO from Sdot first.
Good morning.
Good morning.
I wanted to pass along autumn's sincere apologies for not being able to serve.
She was very excited but some family circumstances got in the way.
By way of quick background.
The transit advisory board was created in 2015 after passage of the 2014 Seattle transportation benefit district proposition 1. the transit advisory board has two main charges.

First advising the city and our partners on transit and transit issues within Seattle and more specifically providing oversight of funds collected and spend under the 2020 Seattle transportation benefit district proposition 1. the board is made up of 12 members.
Six mayoral appointees and one get engaged member.
As mentioned we have one appointment in front of the committee for consideration today.
I will hand it off to Amin to tell us about himself.
Hi, everyone.
Thank you for having me here today.
My name is Amin Amos.
I'm a life long transit use per.
I'm excited to look forward to using established and fresh methods to make using transit a more enjoyable experience in Seattle.
I love the work that's been done so far.
Thank you very much.
We have--got my prop 1 sign here.
We're excited that Seattle voters chose to renew that.
We put various categories in it.

A lot of things, a lot of concerns with West Seattle bridge closed and had we're excited about the new light rail stations opening up trying to coordinate with those light rail stations to get people out of their cars.
Appreciate your willingness to serve on this so we can get more people to ride transit.
Colleagues, any questions for our appointee here?
Really appreciate your willingness to serve.
Thank you.
Colleagues, I'd like to move that the committee recommend approval of appointment 2074 item 3 on our agenda.
Is there a second?
Second.
Thank you.
It's been moved and Seconded to recommend approval of the appointment.
Are there any final comments?
Will the clerk please call the roll.
Gonzalez.
Aye.
Herbold.
Yes.
Morales.
Yes.
Strauss.
Yes.
Chair Pedersen.
Yes.
Five in favor, none opposed.
Thank you.
The motion carries and the committee recommendation that the appointment be confirmed will be sent to the December 6th city council meeting.
Congratulations on advancing.
Appreciate your willingness to serve and for being here this morning.
Thank you.
All right.
We removed item 4 from the agenda.
Next item 5. will the clerk please read the title of the next agenda item into the record.
Agenda item 5. appointment 2076.
Appointment of Robin Schwartz as member, Seattle school traffic safety Committee for a term to March 31, 2023.
For briefing, discussion and possible vote.
Thank you.
And we have another mayoral appointment and this is school traffic safety committee.
Appreciate willingness to serve.
We have Jennifer here from Sdot to tell us about this particular committee and then we'll hear from our appointee.
Good morning, Jennifer.
Morning.
Thank you.
I'm a transportation planner with Sdot and I'm also the Sdot liaison to the school traffic safety committee.
The school traffic safety committee was created in 1975 to bring together Seattle public schools, the city and parents to improve safe routes to schools.
And the committee works closely with Sdot, the Sdot safe school program to make it safer for students to walk and bike to school.

The committee has 11 board members, including representatives from Seattle public schools, Seattle Department of transportation, Seattle police Department, King County Metro and five volunteer positions.
Robin, who is here today would serve one of the volunteer positions.
And I will give Robin a few minutes to introduce herself.
Thanks, everyone.
My name is Robin Schwartz.
Thanks for having me today.
I'm a community member in South park and my younger kid goes to school down here.
That's how I got interested in this.
Making sure, you know, doing what we can to make sure that pedestrian safety is kind of foremost, especially in the last year and a half with the bridge.
I also am really invested in the idea of title I schools organizing together.
You know, high poverty communities find it hard to organize a lot of times and this is when we also have I think more safety pedestrian issues than other communities.
So that's why I'm excited to serve.
I have kind of a network of especially Southwest title I community members.
I'm looking forward to working with them and with the safety committee to make things easier for our kids to get to school.
Thanks.
Thank you very much.

I know the safety committee did a lot of work on their end report and it it was really heartening to see the Seattle public schools working with Sdot and working with community members and one of their proposals was to have the city council fund Gps software for school buses and there's a lot of support for that.
We just because the revenues on the city side went down we weren't able to fund that item.
We tried to do that.
We'll take another look at that in 2022 and then hear what else--what other priority there are.
There are lots of important issues with safe routes to school and crossing guards and other issues.
So Council member Herbold.
Thank you so much.
Just want to add my really strong support for Robin's candidacy.
When she says she has a network of folks she organizes with, she's not kidding.
She's just really somebody that the community finds to be the go to person on so many issues in South park and in the surrounding neighborhoods.
She's been so involved in particular at Concord elementary and on road and pedestrian safety issues.
She's a really excellent fit for this position.
I'm really excited to see that her effective and passionate advocacy is being elevated to a leadership role here.
Thank you.
Excellent.
Thank you.
Committee members, any other comments or questions?
I would like to move that the committee move item.
Is there a second?
Second.
It's been moved and Seconded to recommend approval of the appointment.
Any final comments?
Will the clerk please call the roll.
Gonzalez.
Aye.
Herbold.
Yes.
Morales.
Yes.
Strauss.
Yes.
Chair Pedersen.
Yes.
Five in favor.
None opposed.
The motion carries on the committee recommendation that the appointment be confirmed will be sent to the December 6th city council meeting.
Thank you for serving.
All right.
Will the clerk please read the title of the next agenda item into the record.
Agenda item 6. proposal to waive Street vacation fees for affordable housing projects.
For briefing and discussion.
Thank you.
And I want to thank chair--I want to thank Council member M Mosqueda for sponsoring this legislation.

It impacts Seattle Department of transportation because it's the fees that are paid for the vacating of streets or alleyways and it also affects the office of housing because if it's structured up front they can benefit.
Office of housing can have more funds available for project to increase affordable housing, for example.
Which is a priority of ours.
So we're hearing this item in both committees.
In this committee we're hearing it just as a briefing and discussion.
The real action will take place next week, Tuesday in the Finance and housing committee.
Wanted committee members to hear about this and Council member Mosqueda has been very open to input on this bill.
And she may join us here as well.
We will reach out and let her know we're getting start Odden this one.
We do have central staff here is with us.
Lish Whitson, thank you for your work on this bill.
Why don't we turn it over to you for a presentation and we can ask some questions.
Good morning.
Lish Whitson.
Council central staff.
Council bill bill.
State law allows but in most cases doesn't require the city to require payment of the appraised value of the right of way.
One exception is shoreline street ends where the city must receive the appraised value of the right of way.
The city currently Exempts city, state and Federal agencies from paying these costs.
This bill would also exempt projects that receive city, state, county or federal funding and provide affordable housing at rent and income levels consist with housing and funding policies.
Funds from street vacations under state law are required to be allocated to transportation or open space projects.
Consequently, the effect of the bill would be to reduce transportation funding and reduce costs to build affordable housing when a street vacation is required.
As mentioned the bill will be discussed and potentially voted on at the next housing and Finance Committee meeting.
That's all I have.
Thank you.
Committee members, I'll have a few questions here about the bill but wanted to see if anybody else wanted to go first.
I'll talk very slowly in case Council member Mosqueda wants to join us.
So I'll go ahead and ask a few questions to get us started on this.
Again the voting on this will actually take place the Finance Committee next Tuesday.

So if there are amendments, I think Lish is it fair to say you'd want to receive them this week so you can revise them and get them approved by city attorney's office, et cetera, and then publication potentially on the agenda.
Council member Herbold.
Go ahead.
Sorry.
I didn't mean to--my hand raising interrupt your line of questioning or Lish' response.
No, it's okay.
Lish, is that correct you'd like to get them this week?
Yeah.
Amendments this week would be very helpful.
Thank you.
Okay.
And Council member Herbold, you can go first with your questions.
I know you've got a very deep background on low income housing.
Thank you.
Just and Lish you may have already addressed this and I might have missed it.
But the language here refers to from the Affordability levels for rents as consistent with the housing's funding policies as adopted by Ordnance 125308.
Wondering if you can talk about those Affordability levels.
But also if you could then do what the expectations are as it relates specifically to percentage of affordable housing units.
That would be required.
Sure.
The bill is silent on the percentage of units in the project that would need to be affordable.
They're updated frequently by Council approximately every two years.
They currently require housing to be affordable at 60% or below of area median income.
That's the reference to in the legislation to ordinance 125308?
That's where the 60% is identified?
Yeah.
The most recent amendment was adopted in 2019.
There's a statement of legislative intent that the council passed last month asking for office of housing to recommend some changes to those policies.
They're updated fairly frequently and the idea is to allow for these regulations to change along with those changes to city policy without requiring amendments every couple years.
Those same city policies are silent on the number or percentage of units that are expected for purposes of--I guess this would be sort of a performance requirement?
Correct.
If we wanted to specify that expectation we'd need to offer an amendment.
Correct.
Okay.
Thank you.
Thank you Council member Herbold.
I appreciate that.

I know when we--we all want to have more affordable housing and for the details like that matter tremendously and like you mentioned the percentage of AMI or the Affordability level and then the percentage of units I agree that that's--I don't see that in the bill and Lish, thanks for confirming that.
Maybe that was the intent to have something like that or to reference something.

But if it's not ironclad I would support an amendment to specify the percentage of units basically for those listening in the public, I guess the concept here as I understand it is we are--we want to encourage affordable housing.
There is something the real estate developer's asking for to get the street vacated for free, essentially.
Or the Alleyway for free.
We have to have a public benefit.
But then it's like Okay, devil's in the details.
How affordable is it?
We don't want a project that sets aside 5% of its units for affordable housing then get as free, you know, we vacate the street for no cost.
So as I understand it the--in the mandatory housing Affordability ordinance, one of the main ordinances--the latest one.
I believe Lish, is this correct it's a 40%--at least 40% of the units need to be affordable for it to be exempt from Hma fees?
Yes.
Under the mandatory housing Affordability housing program.
If they have 40% or more of their units affordable at or below 40%.
60% of the area median income.
Okay.
And I think we recently I think the Council recently granted an exemption from the vacation fees of an Alleyway for grant Street Commons in the Mount Baker neighborhood.
I Hi 47% percent of the units were set aside.
As I understand it the low income housing program which is popular, has one of the criteria's 40% of the units must be set aside.
So 40% seems like it would seem to be a logical minimum threshold.
Councilmember Herbold if you're willing to work with it together, I'm happy to put forward an amendment like that with you.
Council President--Oh, go ahead.
I see Council President Gonzalez has her hand up.
I had one other thought on this but I'll hold it to hear from Council President Gonzalez.
Council President.
Thanks so much.

Lish on this conversation related to imposing a percentage, what would the effect be of such a requirement in terms of underlying legislation in the overall Overarching goal of wanting to make it less burdensome to create affordable housing?
Yeah.
So a project that for example has 30% of units at 60% AMI and receives public funding for that to subsidize those units wouldn't have to pay the street vacation fees.
Or compensate the city for the value of the right of way that's being vacated.
So it would increase the cost for those projects.
A project that has over 40% of units affordable under the terms of this legislation would not have to pay those costs.
Okay, so in effect could that result in individuals who are sort of below that threshold because it doesn't pencil out for them to just forgo creating any Creatable housing on site?
Um, you know, I don't know how many projects we receive or are built that includes a mix like that.
But it would weigh into the developer's decision of whether or not to pursue public funding for affordable units in that project.
It would be a project specific decision.

Lish is there a way for you to get information about projects in the--you know sort of historic data on the kinds of projects that we receive that could have or would have been impacted if this legislation included a threshold?
Yeah.
For Street vacation projects generally I know we have only seen projects where 100% of the units were affordable within the structure that was receiving the vacation.
But I will check with the office of housing on whether they are funding projects that include for example 25 or 30% of units affordable.

I think that would be helpful just to get a better understanding that the potential amendment that's currently being discussed would create an unintended consequence in terms of foregoing the construction of affordable housing of any affordable housing units.

I think it's important for the Council to understand what the cost effectively in terms of additional affordable housing units even if it's just a handful of them would be if there is an amendment brought forward that is successful that would require a minimum number.

I think I understand the motivation behind that minimum number, but I think it's Importants for us to have a full understanding of what the potential consequence would be in terms of potential projects that we're seeing coming through the pipeline that would be negatively impacted by such an amendment.
It would be helpful to me if you could gather some of that information, Lish.
Good.
Thank you.
Council member Herbold, did you have a Followup question?
I think it's complementary to the line of questioning from Council President Gonzalez.
It's sort of the flip side of the question which is the issue of like what--how much is the city foregoing with an ordinance like this.
How much is the city not collecting in these fees.
I think that's a, for an average project that's an important thing to potentially take a look at in considering what our expectation is in exchange.

So if a project is as a result of an ordinance like that not going to be credit contributing to the general Fund, you know, X number of hundreds of thousands of dollars and we are getting a single unit of affordable housing in exchange, that's I think something that we need to consider whether or not that is a sufficient value.
So having a little bit more granule Layaway detail about how much funding the city would forego on an average project that would be qualifying under this proposed ordinance would be super helpful.
Okay.
So we have examples of two affordable housing projects that have recently come before the Council and been approved.
Commons which Council approved last month.
We don't have an appraisal of the right of way there.
Based on the assessed value of the property that was granted to be vacated.
Was between 400 and $500,000 for that alley and willow crossing project which was approved at the end of 2019.
They have done an appraisal and that looks like it's in the same ballpark.
So can imagine one project every two years and approximately 400 to $500,000 per project.
Thanks.
So about $500,000 and in those instances they--those--the percentage of units that are affordable in those projects were 40%?
100% of the units in both of those projects were affordable.
Great.
Thank you.
The grant Street project is a bigger project that includes three different sites.
But the Mount Baker housing project is 100% affordable and that's the block where the alley is being vacated.

How does that, chair Pedersen mentioned the Mha regulatory standards for expanded development capacity in exchange for affordable housing development and the ability to be exempt from those fees for affordable housing development.
How does that value to benefit ratio compare to--for Mha compare to 40% for a $500,000 project in this instance?
I do not know.
I will try and see if we can figure that out.
Thank you so much.

Thank you for those questions and appreciate sponsor bringing this forward and I think we can--I think it sounds like there's support for the spirit of this it's just if there are some details that need to be fleshed out a little bit to make sure there are no loopholes.
We do value those Street vacation fees.
We use those for Visionist row projects and other things.
But we also want that affordable housing.
This is the fun part of the job is making the policy choice.
The Tradeoffs and considering those.
It'll be Tuesday at Finance and housing committee where they will vote on this.
We'll get amendments to central staff this week.
I don't think Council member Mosqueda has joined us so I know she'll be speaking to it at length on Tuesday.
All right.
Appreciate it.
Any final questions before we move on?
All right.
Thank you very much, Lish.
Appreciate it.
Will the clerk please read the short title of the next agenda item into the record?
Resolution 32031.
A resolution ratifying the 2021 upgrade to the Green/Duwamish and central Puget sound watershed or water resource inventory area salmon habitat plan.
Thank you very much.
I have introductory remark to this.
I'll let central staff go first.
I want to thank Council member Herbold for her leadership working on this issue.
You know as we know there's several advisory boards that we staff ourselves.
Both staff from the departments as well as Council members serve on these boards.
Transportation and also environmental boards, et cetera.
This is one of them.
So Brian goodnight.
Let us know about this resolution before we turn it over to Seattle public utilities.
Thank you.
Good morning.
For the record, Brian goodnight central staff.
17 jurisdictions that partner in the green, Duwamish and central Puget sound water shed.
This would ratify the 2021 update.
Which was ratified by Council in 2005.
And that was the extent of my remarks since Andrea and Martha and matt are here.
They know more about this than I do.
Yes, thank you.
I think we do have a few people from Seattle public utilities here.
Appreciate interim director Lee being here as well as his team.
Interim director Lee.
If you'd like to start us off.
Thank you, chair Pedersen and members of the committee.
I've met most of you in my capacity and in September I was deeply honored to be selected by Mayor Durkan to serve as interim Ceo.
Just by way of introduction, I first joined Spu in 2006.
And I was involved in the negotiating the consent decree, which led to the ramp up of our program.
I recently rejoined after a brief stint with Bellevue in 2015 as the deputy director for the drainage and waste water line business.
I'm very honored to be here.
With me today is Martha Neuman.
Part of our relations team and matt Goehring for the green, Duwamish River watershed.
Like Council member Pedersen, I would like to recognize Council member Herbold who is Co-Chair for her work on salmon recovery over these many years.
This resolution before you ratifies the habitat plan.

Also known as water resources recovery area 9. the habitat plan identifies an array of recovery strategies and more than 100 capital projects developed among the government jurisdictions in the entire Basin.
The other city councils in this water shed are approving similar resolutions to support this plan.
And so with that I'd like to turn it over to Martha and matt who have a short presentation about the action we're hoping the committee will take this morning.
Thank you.
Good morning, council.
Thank you very much for having us here today.
I'm sharing my screen.
Okay.
Can everybody see my slides?
Not yet.
Not yet.
Okay.
Hang on.
I practiced this this morning.
Okay.
I didn't share correctly.
Hang on.
Share.
Yes.
Yes.
Bingo.
Okay, great.
I'm Martha Neuman.
I'm here with matt Goehring.
So we'll give a quick presentation on why we're here today.
Little bit of overview about the salmon recovery work in the Green/Duwamish and a little bit about the plan.
So I think everybody has covered this well.
The ratification is an update to the plan that was adopted in 2005.
That plan serves as the blueprint for salmon recovery in the Green/Duwamish and as Brian said it will be updated by all the partners who participate in this work.
Okay, quick context about recovery.
So this is about Shinook recovery.
Organized by very large river basins.
So the Puget sound being one.
Within that there are these water resource inventory areas.
The city participants--so why, Hinook the city participants in three of these.
Our interest there is.
The Lake Washington Cedar Sammamish.
Then Wria 9 which is the Green- Duwamish.
So this is kind of a busy slide.
What you see here on the right hand side is the Chinook salmon, you know, the long decline starting in the late 1800S.
You can see the low levels of population we have been experiencing for quite some time.
What you see on the left hand side is the listing and the recovery work.
In 1999, Chinook salmon were listed as threatened under the Federal endangered species act.
Shortly after that the local government started working together which I'll cover in a little bit and have been working together since that time till now.
In 2005 the first recovery plan was put together for the Green- Duwamish.
Then that plan as well as plans for each of those other basins in Puget sound were rolled up into what's called the Puget sound recovery plan for Chinook.
That was approved In2007.
Here we are in 2021 and doing an update to the plan for the Green-Duwamish.
Quick slide about the numbers of fish we see.
This is a little busy here.
So you see these dash lines near the bottom of the slide.
That's called the viable sound population goal.
Those are a variety of factors set by NOAA and national Marine fishery service that would lead to a available Chinook population.
The green line, those are the number of natural returning Spawners.
Those are the Non-Hatchery fish.
You can see those numbers are low.
They've remained low.
Then the blue line shows all of the returning Spawners coming back, including the Hatchery fish.
And matt can correct me if I'm wrong, but I think these numbers look pretty similar to what we see in Puget sound.
We just haven't seen a lot of change over time since the listing.
Okay, so a few facts about the Green-Duwamish watershed.
This is--we are the most urban watershed in Puget sound.
Let's see.
There are 17 local governments who participate in this effort.
And one of the reasons to work together is it really, it's not each jurisdiction going it alone.
Seattle can't say we have this great project but other people don't.
Everybody is working together to agree on what are the most important actions to take for salmon recovery.
So working together in partnership.
Here's a Scum of things we have big things that we have Plushed over the last 20 years.
Over $200 million in investments from local, state and Federal monies.
So levy realignments to restore the shoreline.
Marine shoreline restoration is very important in our areas.
Revegetationest you ware shallow habitat.
We contribute--we've contributed almost $200 million since 2001.
Our annual contribution to that effort is about $120,000.
So the update, the update you can see here the list of what's in there.
Updates the current status.
Incorporates new and updated science.
Updated habitat goals.
Refines the recovery strategies.
There's an updated capital project list and an updated monitoring and Adaptive management plan.
I think one of the main points is this plan has validated the update the original plan.
There are more Tweaks and modifications rather than changes.
This slide is an example, talks about the things that are important in the portions of the Green-Duwamish watershed that are within Seattle.
These areas in the Duwamish are important and critical for juvenile fish.
Those are the small kind of 3 to 5-Centimeter fish.
Protecting and restoring and enhancing the Marine shorelines.
Same for Estuarine habitat.
Improving sediment and water quality.
Revegetating the Riparian corridors.
There's an updated capital project list.
This is really where the dollars should be focused.
You can see 39 near shore projects are included and 19 projects in the Duwamish.
Some of these are city responsibilities.
Including city light, Spu and parks.
The projects range from things like Lowman Beach that you see down here on the left which is matt informs me is in construction right now and Hamm Creek which is still a conceptual project.
People still thinking about what is the right thing to do there.
So by ratifying this plan we are, the city of Seattle is affirming that this is a collaborative watershed approach.
This is a Multibenefit approach.
Not a stand alone action.
So for example, some of the recovery actions also might do things to alleviate local flooding.
Recognizing the plan is the best available source of science together and using the plan to drive the actions.

This is about the rate stabilization account.

It serves to smooth out fluctuations for revenues coming into the city light Fund from the sale of power.
City light as folks I think know SELLS retail power to folks that run gas stations, grocery stores, people at home.
They also sell wholesale power to other utilities, and those revenues can go up or down compared to what's planned for.
The Rsa hopes to smooth that out.
There's a structure to do that that's in the code.
You'll hear about proposals to make adjustments there.

The legislation pertains to the rate stabilization count.
As Eric indicated earlier, the Rsa is a restricted cash reserve that city light uses to ensure we have enough revenue to fund our operations despite uncertainty in the wholesale power market.
If it gets depleted meaning we are not selling as much wholesale power as expected, automatic rate surcharges come on and Refill it.
Those rules are set by ordinance and that is an SMC 214986 for anybody who is interested in that.
As you may remember we were in front of you earlier this year regarding the Rsa and 21 and 22 rates.
With your approval, city light replaced a 3% Rsa surcharge that was due to roll off earlier this year with a 3% rate increase resulting in no change to customer bills in this 2021.
We did this to open sure some rate stability.
So we didn't see a large increase.
Customers didn't see a large increase for 2022.
We'll cover it in more detail in the next slide.
Since we were here there have been changes to the financial picture.
That's why we're here.
As Eric indicated the legislation proposes two amendments to the Rsa.
First a cash deposit from the operating fund into the Rsa to avoid triggering a surcharge.
Secondly, it would authorize changes to the rules that would make it more customer friendly.
If passed it will enable us to keep our promise to customers which is that we wouldn't raise rates in 2021.
Next slide.
Orienting you to the slide, the bar chart shows city light's revenues from surplus power sales.
Everything above the X axis is where the value of the energy we sell is greater than the cost of the energy we buy.
Under normal Hydro conditions city light produces more power than we need.
And we sell that surplus on the wholesale market.
This extra revenue helps keep our rates low.
You can see the yellow bars are positive.
Blue bars are the Actuals as well as our forecast for the rest of the year.
You can see from the blue bar Wes had strong revenue January through March.
Which was when we lifted that SRA surcharge earlier.
From April through August the revenue came in well short of our budget.
There were two reasons for this.
The first 2021 has been a really unusual weather weather year.
For city light the drought meant low Hydro electric generation.
Through the summer city lights in the market rather than selling we were buying at a time when the region was in short supply and prices were expensive.
The other contributing factor is kind of a good news bad news thing.
Besides weather our retail demand that's been higher than we planned for.
This is good news.
Higher demand for electricity from our businesses and residents is an indicator of economic recovery.
It helps city light's bottom line which we'll discuss next.
We had less emergency available to sell.
Combination of these two things means that city light indicates to come in about $35 million short on our $60 million budget for 2021 for wholesale revenue.
To make up for this short fall the Rsa has been drawn down.
It's been drawn down pretty quickly.
Even though the Rsa was full at 100 million, by the end of September it's down to 82 million which for the operating rules would trigger the first 1.5% surcharge.
We don't believe that the surcharge is necessary which is why we're bringing this legislation to you today.
Next slide while the wholesale revenue scenario is not good, our overall picture is excellent.
Nearly $27 million more than we planned.
We've had some favorable purchase power costs from our bulk power sources.
And we also had some help from low interest rates and long term debt refinancing we did earlier this year.
Our bottom line financial target is to have a debt service coverage ratio of 1.8 times.
In short what this means is that we have enough operating cash to deposit some of that--some of those funds back into Rsa.
Section next slide please.
The proposed legislation allows city light.
So long as we maintain a 1.85 times debt service coverage ratio.
The legislation modifies the rules.
This legislation actually proposes to allow city light to only trigger surcharges twice a year whereas currently into the rules and operation today we could do it quarterly.
Someone could have a rate change four times a year.
We're proposing at most two.
This legislation also proposes fewer surcharge steps and leaves those surcharges in place until the Rsa fully Refills.
In the past a new surcharge and incremental surcharge would be triggered every time we're $10 million worse than we thought we were before.
They would trigger at 90, 80, 70.
We're proposing they trigger a little lower at a slightly higher percentage and stay on until the Rsa Refills.
Really driving home that rate stability.
With this legislation just want to say the cash transfer is Reactive and we really need to take that action in 2021.
The proposed rule amendments are really Proactive.
They reflect what we've learned over the decade of observing the Rsa in action.
We can make the Rsa less dynamic and still have it be effective.
Exchanges will provide city light with financial resilience we need to keep our rates low and sustainable for years to come.

Wait a second, what's a conservation target?
A conservation target is the amount of conservation that Seattle city light will acquire by offering rebates, incentives and market interventions.
This is the amount of conservation we will acquire in a two year and ten year period.
So our recommended target is for two years is 18.7 average mega watts.
And this is equivalent to 23,000 homes that average energy use of 23,000 Seattle residential homes.
The recommended ten year target is 76.9.
Initiative 937 passed in 2006 requires governing bodies like you to approve targets every two years.

I thought I would start off by giving some background on the conservation at Seattle city light.
Seattle city light has a long stemming commitment to conservation.
It is really Foundational to how we run but our utility.
We have a long history of conservation at Seattle city light.
We started running our programs back in 1977 and this makes one of--this makes us one of the longest running utility conservation programs in the country.
We offer savings across a portfolio of services and offerings that are offered to all of our customer classes.
Conservation projects have been stalled in residential commercial and industrial facilities throughout our service territory.
So Seattle city light views conservation as a resource and we value conservation for several reasons.
But including because it's a low cost resource it's a low risk resource and because it has low environmental impacts but including no greenhouse gas emissions.
And so by Prioritizing the conservation we have successfully deferred the acquisition of new resources.
And conservation Helpstous maintain our status.
Which we all know will become increasingly important in the future.
Next slide, please.
So what is a potential assessment and why do we do them?
A potential assessment is a year long study that identifies the amount, the timing and cost of energy, conservation within the Seattle city light service territory across the next 20 years.
It is ultimately used to inform and set our conservation goals.
As has been mentioned before.
Requires that utilities identify and pursue all available conservation that is cost effective and then set your targets on to your cycles.
Then in addition the clean energy transformation act commits Washington to supply of greenhouse gas free power by 45 and requires that utilities set four year targets for conservation.

So although we are required by Washington state law to do potential assessments we also use them as inputs to our integrated resource plan, our load forecast and also it helps to inform what we offer to our customers.

This is our Seventh potential assessment, so before I compare these numbers to what I presented to you last time, I thought it would be helpful to review what has changed since 2020.

So there are a few things that has changed and are making potentially go up and go down.
First we're seeing lower potential in CPA than compared to the prior CPA.
Or another way, there's less savings out there for us to go and get.
Some of the main drivers include our long history of conservation.
The huge transformation in the lighting market that we've seen across the past 10 to 15 years and also because we can claim savings just for the savings above code.
Stricter codes and standards are making it harder for us to go and get savings.
The second point I want to make on this slide is is of the savings that remain they tend to be more costly but then the savings we were seeing in the prior CPA.
The reason is much of the low hanging fruit or the cheaper savings like those associated with lighting has already been done or is captured through codes and standards.

And then the last point is that the Washington state law lays out two Methodologies to identify potential and the first approach which could be use the in the last CPA is done at a slightly higher level and is less detailed than the second approach which we shifted to in the CPA.
The second approach values conservation within city light's integrated resource plan.
Slightly more Nuanced model and is better able to reflect the benefits of conservation.
What we saw is with the second model we were seeing higher amounts of conservation than with the first model.
Capture all of the benefits of conservation.

Right hand side to the previous study we presented in 2020.
